title: How to Make a Foam Mousepad

steps.headline: Place the cork plate coaster onto the foam sheet.
steps.description: Place both onto a flat work surface.

steps.headline: Trace around the coaster, transferring its shape to the foam sheet.
steps.description: Use a pen or pencil. Marker will run too easily and leave a mess.

steps.headline: Cut the foam.
steps.description: Follow the template you've just traced out on the foam. Dispose of excess foam, or retain it for some other craft.

steps.headline: Paste or spread glue across the back of the foam sheet you've just cut.
Press the glue-covered side of the foam sheet onto the cork plate coaster.
steps.description: Press down to ensure it adheres evenly and smoothly. Ensure that there are no wrinkles.

steps.headline: Allow to dry.
steps.description: Follow the manufacturer's instructions on drying times.

steps.headline: Trim any excess off.
steps.description: This may not be needed but it's nice to neaten the end result.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: The foam mousepad is now ready for immediate use.

steps.headline: Cut a standard mousepad size from the foam sheet.
steps.description: You can make it larger or smaller if preferred, although the standard size will be around 8.5" x 8". Use the ruler and pencil to measure and mark before cutting.

steps.headline: Measure the same shape for the oilcloth.
steps.description: Cut the oilcloth to the same size.

steps.headline: Go outdoors or in a well-ventilated are for gluing the pieces together.
steps.description: Lay down a protective cover before spraying.

steps.headline: Use adhesive spray the foam piece with the multi-purpose adhesive.
Press the back of the oilcloth onto the foam piece.
steps.description: Take care to smooth it out and remove any wrinkles as quickly as possible.

steps.headline: Create curved corners.
steps.description: Hold the edge of a teacup or similar curved object in the exact same position around all four corners, then snip around this to form the curved edges. Or, do it freehand if you trust your skills. Alternatively, use pinking shears and cut an interesting edging around the entirety of the mousepad, or just down the side edges.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: The mousepad is now ready for regular use.

steps.headline: Find a fabric sample you like.
steps.description: These are often found in dressmaking supplies stores, furniture stores and similar places. Alternatively, just use a piece of scrap fabric you happen to have lying around, although the stronger the fabric, the better the end result.

steps.headline: Cut the foam to the shape and size of choice.
steps.description: You're not limited to the usual rectangle unless you really want it.

steps.headline: Measure and cut the fabric to the same size as the foam pad.
Run a glue stick over the foam that you've already cut to size.
steps.description: Once the glue is in place, gently press down the fabric piece, wrong side facing onto the glue. Use your hand or a ruler to ensure that there are no wrinkles on the fabric. Use a paper cutter to remove any unwanted overhang or excess fabric.

steps.headline: Allow to dry.
steps.description: Once dry, you can seal with a layer of Mod Podge or similar sealant suitable for fabric. While not essential, this makes it easier to remove marks and keep the mousepad clean.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: The mousepad is now ready for use.

tyn: Thick or thin foam sheets (the thickness depends on your preference)
Hot glue gun or standard glue stick
Oilcloth, with an interesting design that you like
Teacup, protractor or other curved item to follow for making rounded corners
Mod Podge or similar sealant and applicator, suitable for fabric
